div.p: A True and Full ACCOUNT OF A CONFERENCE HELD ABOUT RELIGION, BETWEEN Dr. Teni≈øon AND A. PULTON One of the MASTERS in the SAVOY.
London, Printed by Nathaniel Thomp≈øon at the Entrance into Old-Spring-Garden near Charing-Cro≈øs 1687.

A. P. having been Eighteen years out of his own Country, pretends not yet to any Perfection of the Engli≈øh Expre≈ø≈øion or Orthography, wherefore for the future he will crave the favour of treating with the Dr. in Latine, ≈øince the Dr. finds fault with his Engli≈øh.

div.head: To the Indifferent READER.
div.p:
IT was wholly beyond A P's. de≈øign, when he was invited to the Conference, (now ≈øo much noi≈øed through the Kingdom) to proceed ≈øo far as to Print; but as he went to it, as to a private meeting, ≈øo he never intended (being returned home) to make any noi≈øe of it, more than by giving by word of mouth, a ≈øimple account of the whole matter, to ≈øuch as might privately de≈øire to know the ≈øubject, and ≈øucce≈øs thereof. But being alarm'd all Friday, Saturday‚ñ™ and Sunday morning, with reiterated reports of his being run down, and ≈øilenced with five, eight, fifteen of his fellow Je≈øuits, and of the Doctors putting many Que≈øtions to him, without being able to obtain any An≈øwer; at the in≈øtance of many Roman Catholicks, who had been derided by the Dr's Party, as though their cau≈øe had been totally lo≈øt: A. P. thought him≈øelf obliged, after his publick exerci≈øe of Sunday in the Afternoon, to ≈øpeak to his Auditours as followeth; There having been many fal≈øe and ≈øcandalous reports of a late Conference, I conceive many
here pre≈øent may be in expectation, of having now ≈øome account thereof; but it is not our cu≈øtom to give occa≈øion of offence by Pulpit clamours, and making private Affairs publick: And being not yet informed that the Doctor has begun, or countenanced the≈øe reports, I ≈øhall omit at pre≈øent to ≈øay any thing relating thereunto; though, if ju≈øtly provoked, the Sunday following, I ≈øhall give a ≈øincere full, and mode≈øt account of the whole. The Doctor having heard of this, was plea≈øed on Munday in the evening, in company of Dr. Cla. to give A. P. the honour of a vi≈øit in the Savoy, and to u≈øe his own terms, to expo≈øtulate with him, concerning the unbe≈øeemingne≈øs of making ≈øuch Conferences, the ≈øubject of a Pulpit di≈øcour≈øe; adding, that he not having taken tho≈øe mea≈øures, it ≈øeemed rea≈øonable A. P. ≈øhould ≈øpeak of it in that nature, A. P. replied he was content, but that ≈øome means ≈øhould be u≈øed to di≈øabu≈øe the deceived multitude; to which the Dr. an≈øwered, he was willing to pro≈øecute the Que≈øtion propo≈øed, by writing, and that he would An≈øwer the difficulty out of St. Ambro≈øe. But A. P. ≈øaying, that that was the lea≈øt part of his proof, he de≈øired the Dr would allow that he might produce all tho≈øe Te≈øtimonies which he would have alledged in in the Conference it ≈øelf, had not the Dr. refu≈øed to hear them; and that then the Dr. ≈øhould give his
An≈øwer. But the Dr. de≈øiring he might An≈øwer that of St. Ambro≈øe fir≈øt, A. P. a≈ø≈øented, and both ≈øides agreed, that the fir≈øt Copy ≈øhould be mutually ≈øent to the oppo≈øite Party. (Here the Reader is de≈øired to note, that this was the only Agreement made between the Parties in the Savoy) and there was no farther challenge on either ≈øide, much le≈øs, did the Dr. come to ask Pardon, as ≈øome are ≈øaid to have reported. Now here was no mention made of giving, or not giving in writing, a publick account of the meer matter of fact pa≈øt, but only of going on with the points then in debate; and therefore if the Dr. charge A. P. with not ≈øtanding to his agreement, (as he ≈øeems by his Letters to threaten) it will be without ground.

Now A. P. ≈øeeing the fal≈øe and injurious reports daily increa≈øe, and that the Dr's. Party ≈øpread them by written Copies, in Coffee-hou≈øes, thought him≈øelf obliged in ju≈øtice to the Truth, to write ≈øome ≈øhort account of the matter of Fact; the fir≈øt Copy whereof, he ≈øent to the Dr. the Friday following, and then gave ≈øome few to his friends, ≈øo to ≈øtop the Torrent of the fal≈øe and ≈øcandalous reports which ran about the whole City, and great part of the Nation. The Dr. ≈øeemed to take this ill, though without any grounds; he having then compleated a Narrative of ≈øeven or eight ≈øheets. And whereas he ≈øays in his Printed
Copy, that he and A. P. had agreed of following this Method of ≈øetting forth the matter at large, it is far from true, there never having been a word mentioned of it. A. P. ≈øo far as by-hours from greater Employments ≈øhall allow, will ≈øhew that it is the Dr. who in his Narrative has truly inverted the whole Order of the Conference, and ≈ølightly pa≈ø≈øing over the chief ≈øtre≈øs of A. P's. Arguments, and mo≈øt material In≈øtances, has taken pains to Illu≈øtrate his own An≈øwers to certain by-que≈øtions, purpo≈øely thrown in by him to amu≈øe the Auditours, and divert their attention from the chief Argument, and take occa≈øion thence to tax A. P. with not an≈øwering his Que≈øtions. It is de≈øired, that every one will be ≈øo favourable to truth and equity, as to ≈øu≈øpend his judgement, till ≈øuch time as they ≈øhall have read A. P's. Remarks on the Drs. Narrative; by which he will evidence to the World his many mi≈øtakes, mi≈ørepren≈øations, want of ≈øincerity, and his artifice, in confounding the wholematter of fact; and that neither in his Narrative, or Conference, (though much unlike) he has given any ≈øatisfactory An≈øwer to the main Que≈øtion, nor gained any point again≈øt the Roman Catholicks, unle≈øs A. P's. not calling to mind Innocent the III's. Name, or a Ver≈øe of St. Matthew, be a total overthrow of the Roman Catholick Cau≈øe.

div.head: A True and Full RELATION Of the late CONFERENCE BETWEEN Dr. T. & A. P. One of the MASTERS OF THE SAVOY.
div.p: 1. ON Monday the 26th. of September, there came a Youth to A. P. who de≈øired to know, if he was willing to accept a Conference with Dr. H. He an≈øwer'd, he was; but on Tue≈øday it was told him, Dr. T. was the Per≈øon he mu≈øt engage with, at Three in the Afternoon on Thur≈øday follownig.

2. On Thur≈øday, as was appointed, the Parties met, A. P. cume with one Witne≈øs, (no Prie≈øt,) the Dr. alone, who complaining that A. P. came with Attendance, whereas, he had no body in his Company; A. P. reply'd, he thought it rea≈øonable, that ≈øome one ≈øhould be pre≈øent, that might be witne≈øs of all ≈øhould be ≈øaid or done on either ≈øide; But if the Dr. approved not thereof, he was content, the Chamber (which now was almost full of People) ≈øhould be cleared, and that the Dr. with the Youth upon who≈øe account they met, ≈øhould remain alone with A. P. But the Dr. de≈øiring the Man of the Hou≈øe might al≈øo be pre≈øent, A.P. a≈ø≈øented thereto, upon condition he might al≈øo be allow'd likewi≈øe to have one Witne≈øs, to wit, Mr. M. the Dr. excepted again≈øt that Gentleman, and had a private debate with him; Whereupon A. P. was content that Gentleman ≈øhould retire, and pitch'd upon another who ca≈øually came in, tho' not known by name to A. P.

3. Here the Dr. ≈øitting down, invited A. P. al≈øo to place him≈øelf by him, which he did; but de≈øired very much, that Pen, Ink and Paper might be brought, and every thing writ down which ≈øhould be ≈øaid on either ≈øide; but this was not accepted of.

4. The Youth appearing (for who≈øe ≈øake the Conference was) A. P. ≈øaid, That having of late in his Catechi≈øms ≈øhew'd the nece≈ø≈øity of true Faith for Salvation, and of ≈øome a≈ø≈øur'd means to find out the ≈øaid true Faith, which he had ≈øhewn to be a True and Infallible Church; This Youth had been moved, to entertain thoughts of joyning him≈øelf to the Roman Catholick Church; he de≈øired therefore, that the Dr. (if he could) would be pleas'd to a≈ø≈øign a better Rule of Faith, and which might
≈øerve to keep the Youth in the Per≈øua≈øion he had been bred in: The Dr. reply'd, That the Boy had told him no ≈øuch thing, but that A. P. had told him of the contradictions of Luther; and when the Dr. asked him, what Book of Luther it was, the Youth an≈øwer'd, a Book in Quarto; whereupon the Dr. told him, That Luthers Works were not in that Volume, but in Folio. A. P. granted he had ≈øpoke to that purpo≈øe of Luther, and had ≈øhewn that Luther had taught now Seven, then Three, then Two, and at la≈øt only One Sacrament, and there being con≈øequently no Unity in his Doctrine, he had no Spirit of Truth in him: But he ≈øaid, he never had brought any Book to the Pulpit with him; Then the Dr. reply'd, The Boy began with a Lye, to which A. P. reply'd, That did not follow, for he had ≈øhew'd him ≈øuch a Book in his Chamber, which was not any piece of Luther's Works, but had Quotations out of them: At which the Dr. had a fling at Equivocation, ≈øaying, That A. P. had ≈øhew'd him no Book, to wit, in the Pulpit, but he had in his Chamber, to the contradiction of Luther; he ≈øaid the Church of England depended not upon Luther, and that the Roman Church had not always taught Seven Sacraments; to which A. P. reply'd, That the Church then defin'd the preci≈øe number of Sacraments, when the debate began concerning the Nature and E≈ø≈øence of a Sacrament, but had never taught and declared a contrary number: Here A. P. to avoid wandering, pre≈øs'd the Dr. to a≈ø≈øign his Rule of Faith.

5. He having a≈ø≈øigned the Holy Scriptures, A. P. reply'd, There were two things incumbent on the Dr. to prove. 1. That the Volumes he call'd Holy Scripture, were truly ≈øuch. 2. That when ≈øo
prov'd, they were a ≈øufficient Rule by them≈øelves of Faith. But to the Second Point nothing was ≈øaid.

6. To the Fir≈øt the Dr. an≈øwer'd, they had been handed down from the Apo≈øtles. A. P. de≈øired the favour to know, by what hands? The Dr. an≈øwer'd, The Scriptures were prov'd by the Te≈øtimony of Turks, Jews, Gentiles, and Chri≈øtians, and that he had the ≈øame certainty for them, as for there having been ≈øuch a Man as Cicero and Cae≈øar. Here Mr. M. asked the Dr. (who then turning towards him, ≈øeem'd to ≈øpeak to him) whether Turks, Jews, or Gentiles made up part of the Te≈øtimony he alleag'd for Holy Writ? But A. P. de≈øiring that no body ≈øhould argue but him≈øelf, de≈øired to know further of the Dr. from what immediate hands the Church of England had receiv'd their Bible, when ≈øhe began the Reformation? The Dr. an≈øwer'd, from the Univer≈øal Church, and that he meant by the ∆≤niver≈øal Church, all tho≈øe different Bodies which make up the number of Chri≈øtians. Then A. P. urged to know, whether all tho≈øe different Parts made one True and Uncorrupted Body, or whether at lea≈øt there was then any ≈øuch thing, as a True and Uncorrupt Part at lea≈øt of the Whole; But the Dr. would not allow the Whole to be ≈øo, nor yet a≈ø≈øign any Part thereof void of much Corruption.

7. Here a plea≈øant School-Ma≈øter perceiving the Argument to pinch, with wry Mouths and antick Po≈øtures, offer'd to A. P. a Picture (as he ≈øaid) of the Ble≈ø≈øed Trinity: A. P. perceiving that the ≈øtanders by were di≈øpo≈øed to Laughter, reply'd, That God having been pleas'd to appear to the Prophet Daniel under the form of an Antient Man, he ≈øaw no rea≈øon why he might not be Painted as he appeared,
provided one meant not to delineate him in his own Nature; Which ≈øaid, he return'd to his Argument, and pre≈øs'd much to know how the Scripture, having been deliver'd unto them by corrupted, and con≈øequently fal≈øe Witne≈ø≈øes, could be held for the a≈ø≈øured and undoubted Word of God. But the School-Ma≈øter continuing to throw in impertinent Que≈øtions, with many ridiculous ge≈øtures, A. P. ≈øaid, he came not to argue with a Buffoon but a Dr. This was ill taken, and the Dr. was pleas'd to read a Le≈ø≈øon of Charity upon that Subject, and went about to prove, that A. P. had violated the Holy-day: And when Mr. M. ≈øaid in A. P's. defence, That St. Paul had us'd as ≈øharp Language on a like occa≈øion, The Dr. reply'd, were he St. Paul, he might do ≈øo too.

8. Here A. P. perceiving the Dr. willing to enter a Di≈øcour≈øe of a different Subject, he wi≈øh'd Mr. M. to withdraw to the Window, that the Dr. might have no occa≈øion of diverting the Argument, or complaining, there were two again≈øt one; which done, he urged a great while the Dr. to declare, How he was a≈ø≈øured of his Bibles being the True and Uncorrupted Word of God, ≈øince he believ'd all tho≈øe who had delivered it, were Super≈øtitious and Idolatrous, or (at lea≈øt) Fal≈øe and Corrupted: And how, ≈øince he taught they had Corrupted and depraved the Sen≈øe of Holy Scripture, he could believe upon their Authority, the Letter to remain Pure and not Corrupted, u≈øing thereto this Simile, That if one ≈øhould bring a Deed into a Court of Ju≈øtice, atte≈øted only by Lyars and Corrupted Witne≈ø≈øes, although never ≈øo many, it would never make good any Action in Law, or find Credit with any not Corrupted Judge; pre≈ø≈øing this with
much earne≈øtne≈øs, the School-Ma≈øter return'd to his former humours, putting in impertinent Que≈øtions, and ≈øaying, the Buffoon asks this. But A. P. neglecting his impertinences, pre≈øs'd the Dr. continually for a po≈øitive An≈øwer, and the Dr. ≈øaid at la≈øt, There were True Chri≈øtians of an Uncorrupt Doctrine at ≈øuch time as the Reformation began, A. P. pre≈øs'd to know, whether they were vi≈øible or invi≈øible, at that time? If invi≈øible, he de≈øired to be ≈øatisfy'd, how they had taken the Bible from invi≈øible hands? If vi≈øible, where they were? in what Place or Country? But to this never could obtain any ≈øatisfactory An≈øwer.

9. During two hours and a half, which this Debate la≈øted, all their An≈øwers were as follows. Sometimes the D. appeal'd to the Greek-Church, to which A: P. ≈øaid, That he had not then received the Scripture from the Univer≈øal, but a Particular Church, and de≈øired to know, if the Dr. would ≈øtand to that Plea, and be Judged by the Greeks: If ≈øo, A. P. would demon≈øtrate to him, That all the Opinions, or at lea≈øt the Chief wherein the Church of England Di≈ø≈øents from the Roman Catholick Church, were Condemn'd and Anathematiz'd by Two Great Councels called in the Ea≈øt; on tho≈øe Subjects ≈øince the pretended Reformation. Here the Dr. ≈øaid, the Greek-Church had been Corrupted by our Mi≈ø≈øions, which is far from being ≈øo, they having been of the ≈øame Judgement many Hundred Years ago.

10. Then he Appeal'd to the Bohemians; A. P. asked, Whether he would be Judged by them? If ≈øo, he wou'd find, how, although agreeing in ≈øome Points not material, yet in the Sub≈øtance they much
Di≈ø≈øented from the late Reformers, who de≈øcended not at all from them, no more than they from the Apo≈øtles.

11. Here the Dr. again≈øt A. P's. will, importun'd Mr. M. to come from the Window and ≈øit by him, beginning a private Conference with him, which la≈øted a con≈øiderable while; A. P. not being able to obtain of the Dr. a Pro≈øecution of the Que≈øtion in debate, but called for a Bible, which when he would have opened, (I know not on what occa≈øion) A. P. ≈øaid, it was the Que≈øtion in hand to prove that Book to be the Word of God; Then he called for a Greek Te≈øtament, and asked A. P. if he at lea≈øt would allow of the Greek Edition? A. P. reply'd, he allow'd of it, but from his hands could receive neither the one nor the other, unle≈øs he made it out better than he had done yet, that it was the Pure Word of God. The ≈øtanders by ≈øeeing A. P. reject the Greek Te≈øtament, gave a little ≈øhout, as tho' he under≈øtood it not; but A. P. would have ≈øhewn him≈øelf a ≈øufficient Ma≈øter of the Language, had he not been re≈øolv'd to give no occa≈øion of diverting the Di≈øcour≈øe from the main Point.

12. Continuing therefore to urge the Dr. for a po≈øitive An≈øwer, he ≈øaid in the end, This Di≈øcour≈øe, whereby he call'd the Authority of Holy Scripture in Que≈øtion, tended to Athei≈øm: A. P. granted his Po≈øition, and ≈øaid it was true, in their Principles, who having taken all Infallible Authority from the Church, there remain'd none for Holy Writ, which was left to each Man's fancy to receive, reject, or interpret at di≈øcretion; and urged the Dr. very pre≈ø≈øingly, to a≈ø≈øign One Body of Chri≈øtians, which either had held po≈øitively or negatively, as
the Church of England does: And ≈øaid moreover, That if the Church of England were the True Church, ≈øhe mu≈øt derive her Succe≈ø≈øion from the Apo≈øtles; to that the Dr. An≈øwer'd, He mu≈øt have a Library of 10000 l. worth of Books to ≈øhew it. A. P. reply'd, he believ'd it, and added, That had he 100000 l. worth, he wou'd never make it out. Here the Gentleman mentioned above, in the ≈øecond place putting his hand into his Pocket, and taking out a little Volume, ≈øaid, he would ≈øhew the Succe≈ø≈øion of the Roman Catholick Church at a much ea≈øier rate.

13. Here A. P. was over-≈øeen, in letting the Dr. ≈ølip to a new Question upon the occa≈øion of the Succe≈ø≈øion. Where the Dr. deny'd, that St. Peter had ever been had Rome; to which A. P. reply'd, That Calvin him≈øelf, upon account of the general Tradition thereof, granted, that Peter had been put to Death at Rome, tho' he allow'd not of his ≈øitting there 25 years; And although A. P. ≈øaid, it was nothing nece≈ø≈øary for the Truth of our Succe≈ø≈øion, that St. Peter ≈øhould have re≈øided rather at Rome than Antioch: If the Dr. pleas'd, he would make out to him, how, according to true Chronology, he might have re≈øided there 25 years, and produced his Remarks relating to that Subject, and asked the Dr. who had Planted the Chri≈øtian Faith at Rome, of which St. Paul ≈øpeaks in the Fir≈øt Epi≈øtle to the Romans? whereas it is certain, St. Paul had never yet been there; nor any other Apo≈øtle, except St. Peter. But the Dr. ≈øeeing A. P. forward to prove the Point, pa≈øsed to the Que≈øtion of Tran≈øub≈øtantiation, and the Real Pre≈øence.

14. A. P. ≈øeeing there was no An≈øwer to be got to the main Que≈øtion, that he might not ≈øeem to decline a particular Controver≈øy, though he ≈øaid, That was far from the purpo≈øe intended, yet he would yield to the Dr. and accept thereof. Con≈øequently to which he demanded, who the Dr. would be Judged by in this matter? He an≈øwer'd, by the Univer≈øal Church. A. P. demanded, whether by the Univer≈øal Church now extant, or that of the Four Fir≈øt Centuries? If that of the Church now in Being, he had at lea≈øt Five to One again≈øt him; but he reply'd, That his Appeal was to the Four Fir≈øt Centuries; Then A. P. de≈øired all pre≈øent to take notice, that the Dr. would be Judged by the Te≈øtimonies of the Four Fir≈øt Centuries.

15. Here mention was made (I know not on what occa≈øion) of the Council of Lateran, relating to the Real Pre≈øence, when the Dr. asked abruptly, what Pope had pre≈øided at that Council? which not occurring to A.
